questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate, heavily swaddled in warm blankets, develops numerous clear, superficial vesicles over the face, neck and trunk as shown below. The lesions are asymptomatic and rupture easily. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presentation is consistent with Miliaria crystallina, the most superficial form of miliaria, caused by obstruction of eccrine sweat ducts at the level of the stratum corneum. It is common in neonates, particularly following excessive swaddling in warm environments.

Miliaria - Definition:

Disorder of eccrine sweat gland duct obstruction → sweat leakage into skin → inflammatory reaction. Common in hot, humid climates.

Drugs Causing Miliaria:

  • Bethanechol
  • Isotretinoin
  • Doxorubicin

Explanation of Other Options:

Apocrine miliaria (Fox–Fordyce disease) (Option D): A chronic condition with itchy follicular papules in apocrine-rich areas (axilla, anogenital); not seen in neonates.

questions.text: Which is true about eccrine glands?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Eccrine glands are present all over the body, function from birth, and play a key role in thermoregulation.

Modified apocrine glands:

  • Mammary glands
  • Ceruminous glands (in external auditory canal)
  • Moll’s glands (in eyelids)

questions.text: The following image shows:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows features consistent with Acne inversa, also known as Hidradenitis Suppurativa (HS), a chronic, relapsing inflammatory disease of apocrine gland–bearing areas.

Explanation of Other Options:

Acne Fulminans (Option B):

  • This is an acute, explosive form of nodulocystic acne that primarily affects adolescent males and presents with ulcerative, hemorrhagic nodules over the face, chest, back.
  • Unlike hidradenitis suppurativa (HS), acne fulminans has systemic features such as fever, malaise, and arthralgia; it lacks sinus tracts and rope-like scarring.

Acne Conglobata (Option C):

  • A chronic, severe variant of acne marked by grouped comedones, tender nodules, abscesses, draining sinuses, and disfiguring hypertrophic or atrophic scars—commonly on the trunk, upper limbs, and buttocks. It lacks systemic symptoms.
  • Unlike HS, it does not show predilection for intertriginous areas (e.g., axillae, groin), lacks bridging scars, and typically presents with comedonal acne history rather than follicular occlusion alone.

Acne Vulgaris (Option D):

  • This is the most common form of acne, characterized by comedones, inflammatory papules, pustules, and occasional nodules, primarily affecting the face, chest, and back.
  • It may result in post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation or scarring but does not form sinus tracts or tunnels.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the follicular occlusion tetrad?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acne fulminans is not a part of follicular occlusion tetrad, as it lacks the chronic follicular occlusion and sinus tract formation seen in the tetrad.

The follicular occlusion tetrad is a group of interrelated dermatological conditions characterized by chronic follicular occlusion, inflammation, and scarring. The four disorders that make up this tetrad are:

  1. Hidradenitis Suppurativa (HS) – also called Acne inversa (Option B ruled out)
  2. Acne conglobata (Option C ruled out)
  3. Dissecting cellulitis of the scalp
  4. Pilonidal sinus/cyst (Option A ruled out)

These conditions share common pathophysiologic mechanisms involving occlusion of hair follicles and subsequent inflammation, infection, and scarring.

Follicular Occlusion Triad: Acne conglobata + Dissecting cellulitis of the scalp + Pilonidal sinus

questions.text: A 20-year-old girl presents with multiple lesions in the axilla, as shown in the image. Which of the following statements is not true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario describes Fox–Fordyce disease (apocrine miliaria), a chronic, non-infectious inflammatory disorder of the apocrine sweat glands. It typically affects young women and is not associated with malignancies.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding Fordyce spots except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fordyce spots are ectopic (heterotopic) sebaceous glands (Option A ruled out), meaning they are not associated with hair follicles.
  • They are benign and asymptomatic. (Option B ruled out)
  • Commonly appear on:
    • Upper lip (most common site) (Option D ruled out)
    • Oral mucosa
    • Genitalia (penis, scrotum, vulva)
    • Tongue
  • Appear as pinhead-sized, yellowish or skin-colored, maculopapular lesions.
  • Typically appear at puberty.
  • More common in males.
  • No treatment is required; reassurance is sufficient.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with comedones, papules, and pustules on her face and back. Histopathology of an early lesion reveals follicular hyperkeratinization, increased sebaceous gland activity, and perifollicular inflammation with neutrophilic infiltrate. The primary anatomical unit involved in this condition is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The combination of comedones, papules, pustules, and histologic features (follicular plugging, sebaceous hyperactivity, and perifollicular inflammation) is characteristic of acne vulgaris.

The pilosebaceous unit includes the hair follicle, sebaceous gland, and duct, which are all integral to the development of acne.

Acne is not a disease of the sebaceous gland alone, but of the entire pilosebaceous complex.

Pathogenesis of Acne:

There are 4 main factors that contribute to acne:

  • Follicular hyperkeratinization: Excess keratinocyte proliferation leads to obstruction of the pilosebaceous duct and formation of comedones.
  • Seborrhoea: Androgen-induced overproduction of sebum creates a lipid-rich environment.
  • Cutibacterium acnes (formerly Propionibacterium acnes) colonization: This anaerobic bacterium thrives in the lipid-rich sebum, breaks down triglycerides into pro-inflammatory fatty acids, and stimulates a host immune response.
  • Inflammation: Both primary and secondary, driven mainly by IL-1α, it underlies the progression from comedones to inflammatory lesions (papules, pustules, and nodules).

Exacerbating and Aggravating Factors in Acne Vulgaris

  • Hormonal: Premenstrual flares, GH excess, insulin resistance (e.g., PCOS)
  • Diet: High glycemic foods, dairy → ↑ IGF-1 → ductal blockage
  • Stress: Emotional stress and anxiety worsen inflammation
  • Climate: Hot, humid weather promotes follicular occlusion
  • Cosmetics: Oil-based products block pores
  • Genetics: Family history increases risk

Explanation of Other Options:

Eccrine sweat gland complex (Option A):

  • These are involved in thermoregulation via sweat secretion.
  • They are not associated with hair follicles and play no role in comedogenesis or acne pathophysiology.

Apocrine gland and terminal follicle (Option B):

  • Apocrine glands open into hair follicles but are found in specific areas (axilla, groin) and become active after puberty.
  • They are primarily involved in conditions like hidradenitis suppurativa, not acne.

Isolated sebaceous gland lobules (Option D):

  • Sebaceous glands by themselves are not functional without the associated follicular component.
  • Comedone formation and inflammatory acne lesions require the full pilosebaceous apparatus, not just isolated glands.

questions.text: A 21-year-old patient with a history of anxiety disorder presents with lesions as shown in the picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient’s presentation is consistent with Acne excoriée (also known as picker’s acne), which is a psychodermatological disorder, characterized by conscious, repetitive picking of acne or even imagined blemishes. It is most often seen in young women, but can occur in males.

  • Seen in patients with underlying psychiatric comorbidities: OCD, body dysmorphic disorder (BDD), anxiety.
  • Picking leads to linear erosions, ulcerations, crusting, and post-inflammatory hypo-/hyperpigmentation or scarring.
  • Picking behavior is impulsive, conscious, and causes distress or impairment.
  • Diagnosis supported by presence of both acneiform lesions and secondary excoriations.
  • Management: Combination of acne treatment (topical/systemic), psychological therapy (CBT, habit reversal), and SSRIs (like fluoxetine or sertraline) if needed.

Explanation of Other Options:

Acne mechanica (Option A): Occurs due to mechanical friction (helmets, straps, sports gear). Lesions are usually monomorphic papules/pustules in pressure/friction zones. No compulsive picking involved.

Acne fulminans (Option C): Severe, sudden-onset ulcerative acne with systemic symptoms like fever, arthralgia, and malaise. It presents with inflammatory nodules with necrosis, not due to picking.

Acne conglobata (Option D): Chronic, severe nodulocystic acne with sinus tracts and scarring. Typically affects males. No psychiatric component or picking behavior.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male is undergoing long-term treatment for acne. He now presents with bluish-black pigmentation over acne scars, as shown in the image. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Minocycline, a tetracycline antibiotic, can cause blue-black pigmentation in areas of previous inflammation such as acne scars (Type I pigmentation). The discoloration is due to iron-minocycline chelates or minocycline-melanin complexes.

  • Pigmentation is dose- and duration-dependent but may occur even with short-term use.
  • Common sites: skin, nails, oral mucosa, sclera, bones.

Types of Minocycline-Induced Pigmentation:

  • Type I: Blue-black macules in acne scars (most common)
  • Type II: Blue-grey patches on sun-exposed areas (shins, ankles, arms)
  • Type III: Diffuse symmetrical brown-grey discoloration ("muddy skin syndrome"); photoaggravated
  • Type IV: Blue pigmentation on vermilion of lower lip

Most pigmentation improves after stopping the drug; laser therapy (e.g., Q-switched laser) may be considered if persistent.

Explanation of Other Options:

Lichen Planus Pigmentosus (Option A):

  • Presents as diffuse slate-gray or dark brown macules, commonly on sun-exposed areas and flexures (face, neck, axillae).
  • It does not follow acne scars and lacks the blue-black hue typical of minocycline pigmentation.
  • Histology shows interface dermatitis and basal cell degeneration.

Fixed Drug Eruption (FDE) (Option B):

  • FDE appears as well-demarcated dusky red to violaceous patches, often recurrent at the same site.
  • Common sites: lips, genitals, hands.
  • Leaves hyperpigmentation after resolution but is not bluish-black, nor does it follow acne scars.
  • Common causes: NSAIDs, sulfonamides, tetracyclines.

Nevus of Ota (Option D):

  • A congenital dermal melanocytosis.
  • Presents as bluish-gray patch involving periorbital skin, sclera, and sometimes mucosa.
  • Usually unilateral, appears at birth or puberty.
  • Not associated with drug use or acne scars.

questions.text: A patient with pre-existing acne lesions was treated with long-term tetracyclines. Subsequently, they developed multiple papulopustules and nodules predominantly around the nose and lips. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given presentation is consistent with Gram-negative folliculitis. 

Explanation of Other Options:

Morbihan disease (Option A):

  • Rare complication of acne/rosacea or seen in Melkersson–Rosenthal syndrome.
  • Presents as woody, non-pitting edema of the midface (nose, cheeks, eyelids), not pustules/nodules.
  • Caused by hypoplastic lymphatics leading to progressive soft tissue swelling and facial distortion.

Chloracne (Option B):

  • Occurs after exposure to halogenated aromatic hydrocarbons (e.g., dioxins).
  • Characterized by multiple comedones and cysts, often on retroauricular, malar, and mandibular areas.

Rosacea (Option D):

  • Common in middle-aged adults.
  • Presents with central facial erythema, flushing, papules, pustules, and sometimes rhinophyma.
  • Lesions are typically chronic, not sudden-onset, and not specifically perioral/perinasal.

questions.text: SAPHO syndrome includes all of the following features except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Scleritis is not a component of SAPHO syndrome. It is more commonly associated with systemic autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis or granulomatosis with polyangiitis.

SAPHO syndrome:

It is a chronic autoinflammatory disorder characterized by a combination of:

  • Synovitis
  • Acne: Acne fulminans, conglobata, and hidradenitis suppurativa (more in males) (Option A ruled out)
  • Pustulosis (especially palmoplantar)
  • Hyperostosis (Option B ruled out)
  • Osteitis (Option C ruled out)

It typically affects the skin, bones, and joints. It is sometimes considered part of the spondyloarthropathy spectrum due to overlapping features like axial involvement.

Cutibacterium acnes has been isolated in some bony lesions, but the lesions do not improve with antibiotics → suggests immune-driven inflammation

Treatment:

  • Bisphosphonates help bone symptoms (no effect on skin)
  • Biological agents like TNF-α inhibitors (e.g., infliximab) and IL-12/23 inhibitors (e.g., ustekinumab) have shown benefit in some cases
  • Paradoxical effects:
    • TNF-α inhibitors: joint relief but possible skin flare
    • Isotretinoin: improves acne but may worsen joint pain

questions.text: 40-year old woman presents with a 2 year history of erythematous papulopustular lesions on a background of erythema and telangiectasia. The most likely diagnosis in the patient is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture is classic for rosacea, especially the papulopustular subtype, which commonly presents with:

  • Chronic central facial erythema,
  • Erythematous papules and pustules,
  • Telangiectasias, and
  • Flushing

This patient shows nontransient erythema, papules and pustules, and telangiectasia, all of which are primary diagnostic features of rosacea.

Rosacea:

  • Epidemiology: Common in middle-aged, fair-skinned women.
  • Typical distribution: Central convexities of the face (cheeks, nose, forehead, and chin) with sparing of perioral and periocular areas.

Explanation of Other Options:

Acne vulgaris (Option A):

  • Acne vulgaris typically presents with comedones (open and closed), which are absent in rosacea.
  • Onset is usually in adolescents, not middle-aged adults.
  • Lacks flushing or telangiectasia, which are prominent features in rosacea.

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) (Option C):

  • Can cause a malar rash over the cheeks and nose, but it:
    • Spares the nasolabial folds, unlike rosacea.
    • Is usually non-pustular and associated with systemic signs (e.g., joint pain, photosensitivity, fatigue).

Dermatomyositis (Option D):

  • Characterized by heliotrope rash (reddish purple discoloration of skin of upper eyelids), Gottron’s papules, and muscle weakness.
  • Photosensitive facial erythema, sometimes involving the malar region. However, the rash typically involves the nasolabial folds, unlike SLE, which spares them.
  • Papulopustular lesions are not a feature of dermatomyositis.

Key Takeaway:

choices.text: Increased reactivity of cutaneous blood vessels to vasodilators
Allergic contact dermatitis due to type 4 hypersesitivity

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 2 year old history of erythema on the face and complain of burning sensation on consuming hot/spicy food. The main pathogenesis of this disorder is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient’s history of central facial erythema, burning on spicy food intake, and absence of comedones is characteristic of rosacea, particularly the erythematotelangiectatic subtype.

Etiology and Pathogenesis of Rosacea:

  • Central mechanism: Abnormal vasomotor response leading to persistent vasodilation and neurovascular dysregulation.
  • Increased reactivity of cutaneous vessels to triggers (e.g., heat, spicy food, alcohol, stress) → leads to flushing, erythema, and later, telangiectasia.
  • Other contributing mechanisms:
    • Innate immune system dysregulation: ↑ cathelicidin and kallikrein 5 activity → inflammation.
    • Microorganisms: Demodex folliculorum mites may aggravate inflammation.
    • UV exposure: Increases oxidative stress and VEGF.
    • Neurogenic inflammation: TRPV1 receptors mediate burning and stinging.

Explanation of Other Options:

Auto-antibodies against nucleic acids (Option A):

  • This is characteristic of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), not rosacea.
  • SLE presents with:
    • Malar (butterfly) rash that spares the nasolabial folds, unlike rosacea.
    • Systemic features: arthritis, renal involvement, cytopenias.
    • ANA, anti-dsDNA, and anti-Smith antibodies are common in SLE.

Hair follicle occlusion and seborrhoea (Option B):

  • This describes the pathogenesis of acne vulgaris, not rosacea.
  • Acne involves:
    • Comedones (open and closed),
    • Inflammation due to Cutibacterium acnes,
    • Increased sebum production due to androgens.
  • Rosacea lacks comedones and is not related to seborrhea or follicular occlusion.

Allergic contact dermatitis due to type 4 hypersensitivity (Option D):

  • This refers to a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction (T-cell mediated), typical in:
    • Allergic contact dermatitis from substances like nickel, fragrances, or cosmetics.
    • Presents with itchy, eczematous lesions often in areas of contact.
  • Rosacea is not mediated by type IV hypersensitivity

questions.text: The condition seen in the illustration is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical image shows rhinophyma, a subtype of phymatous rosacea, which is a chronic inflammatory condition, characterized by progressive hypertrophy of the sebaceous glands and connective tissue of the nose.
  • Rhinophyma is the most common site of phyma, though phymatous changes can also involve:
    • Chin (gnatophyma)
    • Ears (otophyma)
    • Forehead (metophyma)
    • Eyelids (blepharophyma)

Rhinophymoma:

Epidemiology:

  • Most often seen in white men between the 5th and 7th decades.
  • Rare in women and uncommon in Asian and African populations.

Clinical Features:

  • May follow inflammatory lesions or appear de novo.
  • Characterized by:
    • Thickened skin
    • Prominent follicular openings
    • Tortuous telangiectasias
    • Peau d’orange appearance
    • Erythematous papules/pustules
    • Oily skin and malodor with manipulation
    • In advanced cases, soft tissue distortion with bulbous nasal protuberances

Treatment:

  • Surgical debridement
  • CO2 laser

Explanation of Other Options:

Acne vulgaris (Option B): Typically involves comedones, cysts, and pustules. It lacks skin thickening or sebaceous gland hypertrophy as seen in rhinophyma.

Affects the scalp (Option C): Rhinophyma affects the nose, not the scalp.

Dermatofibroma (Option D): A benign fibrous skin nodule, unrelated to rosacea or sebaceous gland proliferation.

questions.text: A 35 year old obese female with hirsutism presents with lesions as shown. She is not responding to isotretinoin and antibiotics. What is the next step ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows acne over the lower face (jawline and chin – “beard distribution”) with terminal black hair (hirsutism), suggesting hormonal acne.
  • The patient is not responding to standard acne treatments including oral antibiotics and isotretinoin, raising suspicion for underlying endocrine pathology.
  • Hence, the next step in evaluation is to assess for hyperandrogenism.

Hormonal (Androgen-Mediated) Acne:

  • Distribution: Lower face, jawline, chin (“beard area”)
  • Features:
    • New-onset adult acne
    • Premenstrual flare
    • Deep, cystic lesions
    • Associated with hirsutism, menstrual irregularities
  • Pathophysiology: Cyclical flares related to androgen fluctuations

Clinical Features of Hyperandrogenism in Females

  • Acne, seborrhea/oily skin
  • Hirsutism
  • Irregular menstrual cycles
  • Acanthosis nigricans
  • Androgenetic alopecia
  • Obesity and insulin resistance
  • Cushingoid facies (if adrenal tumors are involved)
  • Clitoromegaly, deepened voice, increased libido
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus (due to insulin resistance)

Syndromes Associated with Hyperandrogenism and Acne

  • Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
  • Cushing’s syndrome
  • Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)
  • HAIR-AN syndrome (HyperAndrogenism, Insulin Resistance, AN)
  • SAHA syndrome (Seborrhea, Acne, Hirsutism, Androgenetic alopecia)
  • Acromegaly
  • SAPHO syndrome (Synovitis, Acne, Pustulosis, Hyperostosis, Osteitis)
  • PAPA syndrome (Pyogenic Arthritis, Pyoderma Gangrenosum, Acne Conglobata)
  • Apert syndrome (Acrocephalosyndactyly type I)

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Antibiotic resistance (Option A): These patients still respond to isotretinoin.
  • Triggering drugs (Option B): No drug history is mentioned; drug-induced acne usually presents as monomorphic papules on chest/back, not with hirsutism.
  • Dietary triggers (Option C): High-glycemic diet may worsen acne but doesn’t cause severe, treatment-resistant acne with hirsutism. Also, these patients respond to isotretinoin.

questions.text: The 3-day-old infant pictured has a facial rash. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Neonatal acne (acne neonatorum) is a common condition seen in newborns, typically presenting within the first 4 weeks of life, often even at birth.

  • Clinical features: Small closed comedones, especially over the forehead, nose, and cheeks. Less commonly, open comedones, papules, or pustules may appear.
  • Etiology: Caused by passive transfer of maternal androgens across the placenta during the third trimester, leading to stimulation of sebaceous glands in the neonate.
  • Prevalence: Affects up to 20% of neonates.
  • Natural history: Usually self-limiting, resolving without scarring in a few weeks to months.

Explanation of Other Options:

Herpes simplex virus (Option A): Presents as grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, often with systemic features (e.g., fever, lethargy).

Milia (Option C): Tiny white papules, typically present at birth, due to retained keratin in pilosebaceous follicles; no comedones.

Seborrheic dermatitis (Option D): Greasy yellowish scales, often involving scalp (cradle cap) and intertriginous areas, not limited to cheeks.

questions.text: Which of the following is a correctly matched pair of sweat gland type and its associated disorder?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bromhidrosis is the apocrine gland disorder.

questions.text: A 21-year-old unmarried woman presents with lesions on her face (as shown in the image), upper back, and shoulders for the past 2 years. What is the drug of choice for her treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical image and description are consistent with Grade 4 (nodulocystic) acne, the most severe form.

Oral isotretinoin is the most effective treatment as it targets all major pathogenic mechanisms in acne: excessive sebum production, comedogenesis, Cutibacterium acnes proliferation, and inflammation.

  • Dose - 0.5-1 mg/kg/day
    Total cumulative dose: 120 -150 mg/kg
  • Precautions: Negative UPT before starting, Double contraception during and for 1 month after
  • Adverse effects:
    • Most common: Cheilitis (dry, Chapped lips)
    • Most important: Teratogenic
    • Others: Hypertriglyceridemia, Hepatitis → (Monitor LFT & lipid profile)

Treatment of Acne Vulgaris Based on Grading:

Explanation of Other Options:

Doxycycline (Option A):

  • This oral antibiotic is commonly used in moderate inflammatory acne (Grade 2–3), especially papulopustular types.
  • It reduces acnes and has anti-inflammatory effects, but not sufficient alone for nodulocystic (Grade 4) acne.

Topical Benzoyl Peroxide (Option B):

  • Effective in mild to moderate acne; it kills acnes and reduces inflammation.
  • In severe acne, it's used only as an adjunct, not as monotherapy.

Salicylic Acid Peel (Option D):

  • A chemical exfoliant used for comedonal acne or post-acne pigmentation.
  • Not effective for deep nodules or cysts, hence not suitable for Grade 4 acne.

questions.text: A 45-year-old fair-skinned woman presents with a 6-month history of facial flushing and persistent erythema over the central face. She also reports burning sensation and dryness. Clinical diagnosis of erythematotelangiectatic rosacea is made. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

For erythematotelangiectatic rosacea characterized by persistent erythema and flushing, the first-line management includes:

  • General skin care and avoidance of known triggers, and
  • Topical α-adrenergic agents such as brimonidine 0.33% gel or oxymetazoline 1% cream, applied once daily to reduce persistent vasodilation.

Management of Rosacea:

General Measures (for all patients)

  • Use broad-spectrum sunscreen regularly
  • Avoid known triggers (e.g., sun exposure, spicy food, alcohol, hot beverages, emotional stress)
  • Avoid topical corticosteroids (can worsen rosacea)

Transient Erythema (Flushing subtype):

  • Topical α-adrenergic agonists:
    • Brimonidine 0.33% gel
      • Mechanism: α2-agonist → vasoconstriction → reduces persistent erythema
      • Onset ~30 minutes, duration ~12 hours.
    • Oxymetazoline 1% cream (alternative)

Phymatous Rosacea (Rhinophyma):

  • Surgical or laser-based debulking: CO2 laser ablation, Electrosurgery, Surgical excision

Ocular Rosacea:

  • First-line:
    • Lid hygiene, warm compresses, Artificial tears
    • Omega-3 fatty acid supplementation
  • Second-line: Topical agents to lid margins like
    • Ciclosporin 0.05% eye drops
    • Azithromycin or tacrolimus
    • Ivermectin or metronidazole gel
  • Third-line:
    • Systemic antibiotics: Doxycycline, Minocycline, Azithromycin

Explanation of Other options:

Doxycycline (Option A): Used as second-line therapy for inflammatory lesions (papules/pustules), not flushing/erythema.

Isotretinoin (Option C): Reserved for severe or refractory inflammatory or phymatous rosacea.

Electrosurgery (Option D): Used for treating telangiectasia or non-inflammatory phymatous changes, not early erythematous stages.

questions.text: Match the following nail changes with their associated conditions:

A 28-year-old housemaid presents with redness and swelling around several fingernails. Examination reveals loss of the cuticle, discoloration, and roughness of the nail plate. She frequently performs household chores involving prolonged water exposure and use of detergents. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient has features typical of chronic paronychia-loss of cuticle, nail plate changes, and a history of wet work exposure, which is classic for irritant dermatitis with secondary Candida infection.

Explanation of Other Options:

Herpetic paronychia (Option C):

  • aka Herpetic whitlow; Caused by HSV-1/2, typically in children, medical/dental personnel, or due to autoinoculation.
  • Presents with intensely painful swelling and grouped vesicles, often confused with bacterial paronychia.
  • May be associated with systemic symptoms or lymphangitis, unlike this chronic presentation.

Orf paronychia (Option D):

  • Zoonotic parapoxvirus infection from contact with sheep or goats (e.g., farmers, vets).
  • Presents as a single lesion with distinct stages (maculopapular → weeping → crusted → resolution).

choices.text: Itraconazole pulse therapy requires 2 pulses for toenail involvement
Proximal subungual onychomycosis is associated with HIV infection
Filamentous fungi like Fusarium and Aspergillus can cause onychomycosis
Topical antifungals are preferred in with liver disease

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding onychomycosis is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Itraconazole pulse therapy for onychomycosis requires 2 pulses for fingernail and 3 pulses for toenail involvement.
